721217f.text:
Old Madison Avenue. The building with the ornate grilled iron balconies, was originally the home of Lawrence(Larry), Jerome, the father of Mr. Travers Jerome. In 1953 the home of the Manhattan Club. The building on North East corner was the former Madison Square Gardon between E.26th and 27th Streets. It was replaced,in 1890 by the present structure.
0N RN6 SfeA. IE70
Cc,E Mey ISth.1931.
Ewing Galloway,Photograpy-.
Credit Line Imperative.
permission for reproduction.

721230f.text:
Madison Avenue, north across East 26th Street.  Occupying the easterly frontage, from 26th to 27th Streets is the first Madison Square Garden.  It was the abandonded passenger station of the N.Y. Central and Hudson River Railroad. Because of a series of band concerts under F.S. Gilmore, it popularily became Gilmore's Garden. Serving this purpose for twenty years it was removed for the second Madison Square Garden designed by Stanford White. On the right is the University Club, organized in 1865.  The 5-story brownstone  site at teh left will (after about 1895) house the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Between 1870 and 1890

Ewing Galloway
NO REPRODUCTIONS

721226f-a.text:
Madison Ave. So. from 26th St.  1890
Brown stone houses and in the distance Dr. Parkhursts Church In the house in the foreground lived Jennie Jerome who became Lady Churchill and was the mother of the present English war
lord Winston Churchill.
Photograph By
Brown Brothers
1482 Broadway, N.Y.

721511f.text:
"Diana" on Madison Square Garden New York City.  "Diana", a figure heroic size erected on tower of Madison Square Garden, one of the largest buildings in America devoted to amusements and large gatherings.  It occupies entire block between Madison and fourth avenues and 26th and 27th Streets, East.  It opened on June 16, 1890.

Underwood and Underwood photogs.

721225f-a.text:
Madison avenue at 26th Street, seen from Madison Siuare. The house with the flagpole, on the right, was once the Lawrence Jerome residence, and is now the University Club. Later it will house
the Manhattan Club.
Of principal interest, however, is the new Madison Sguare Garden at the left. For about twenty years before its erection, the first Madison Suuare Garden, which was once the New York Central station, occupied the site. Work was begun on the second Garden in
1889, and it opened on June 16, 1890.
The figure of Diana is of special interest. This statue, by St. Gaudens, will be removed in September,1892, and sent to Chicago for the World's Fair. A second statue will be made by St. Gaudens and placed on the tower in 1893, where it will remain until removed for the demolition of the building in 1925.
Mbout 1890.
A copy of tnis view also occurs in a volume of Photo hs of Madison Sduare Garden presenting a pictorial s ory o e

721491f.text:
A general view of the Madison Square area, photographed from the Fuller (Flatiron) Building.  Fifth Avenue is on the left and Madison Avenue on the right.  East 26th Street forms the northerly margin of the park.  The distinctive Madison Square Garden is silhouetted against the nondescript district fringing Murray Hill.  On the lower right is the recently erected Appellate Division of the Supreme Court Building.

Close observation thru the center discloses the cleared site of the fire-destroyed 71st Regiment Armory at 34th Street and Fourth Avenue.  Upon 5th Avenue are observed, the Marble Collegiate Church, the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, the Brick Presbyterian Church, the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas and St. Thomas F.E. Church.  The spires of St. Patricks Cathedral are outlined against the Hotel Sherry-Netherland.  On the lower left is building debris at the S.W. corner of 5th Avenue and 26th Street.  A structure there, that adjoined the corner (No. 202 Fifth Avenue) was removed in June of 1902.

About 1902

Ewing Galloway

721237f-a.text:
Madison Avenue between E.26th and E.27th Streets, looking in a northeasterly direction across the Madison Square Garden.

Detroit Photo Company  1900

721241f-a.text:
Madison Square Garden, Madison Ave, east side, from and including 28th to 27th Streets. The view also shows 26th Street, north side, from and including Madison to Fourth Aves.

About 1900

Wurts Brothers

721520f.text:
Madison Square, looking southwest across the park from Madison Avenue and 26th Street, a singularly beautiful night view showing the Flatiron Building, and the new Fifth Avenue Building on the site of the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The low building to the right is the old Albenarie building, formerly the hotel of that name; it will shortly be replaced by a more modern structure.

In the foreground, the statue of President Chester A. Arthur is rather prominent.

1911.
New York Edison Company Collection.

721510f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, from East 26th to 27th Streets. This photo shows the statue of Diana that stood atop the tower of the old Madison Square Garden. A replica of this is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the original being in Philadelphia.
1912
Copyright, 1912
Geo. P. Hall, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

721234f-a.text:
WHERE THE DEMOCRATIC CAIDIDATE WILL BE PICKED#
New view of Madison Square Garden, taken from Madison Square Park, New York, today--herre the Democratic National Convention will be opened on June 24 next, the party platform made up, the candidate for President will be nominated, New York won the right to the convention in the auction at Washington
yesterday, bidding $255,O00.
Jan. 16, 1924  Underwood & Underwood
Madison Square Garden is the largest auditorium in the metropolis. The building covers an entire block. It is one of the architectural achievements of the late Stanford White.

721231f-a.text:
Madison avenue, east side, north from and including 26th Street. At the extreme right is the former Lawrence Jerome residence, now the Manhattan Club, which will still stand in 1935. Beyond it is the second Madison Sguare Garden (18891925). The Madison Avenue porticos on the Garden are being removed to
perm.t the widening of Madison Avenue.
ugust 13, 1924.
Eugene L. armbuster Colleetion.

721233f-a.text:
Madison SCuare Garden, on N.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 26th Street, during the Democratic Convention of 1924 which was memorable for the Smith-McAdoo deadlock. On the S.E. corner is shown the Manhattan Club, occupying the old Lawrence Jerome
residence.
Summer 1924.

721236f-a.text:
Madison Ave., west side, north from and including East 26th to, but not including East 27th Streets. Building shown is the headcuarters of the American Society For The Prevention of Cruelty To Animals. Madison Square Park appears on the right. The foreground shows the site of the old Madison Square, being cleared for the New York Life Insurance
Building.
July 9, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.

721224f.text:
New York Life Insurance Company Building, Madison Avenue at N.E. corner of 26th Street, shortly after its completion, on the site of the old Madison Square Garden. Cass Gilbert was the architect.
1929.
Browning Studios.

721220f.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, at 26th Street, showing the New York Life Insurance Company Building, on the N. E. corner, and the Manhattan Club, once the Lawrence Jerome residence, on the
S. E. dorner.
The New York Life acquired this site in 1915 by forecloslng a mortgage on Madison SQuare Garden, which had occupied this site since 1889. In 1925 they decided to demolish the masterpiece of Stanford White, and to erect their own building, designed by Cass Gilbert, in its place.
About 1929.
Browning Studios.

721228f-a.text:
University Club, Madison Avenue at S.E. corner of 26th Street. This is the old Jerome residence, owned by Lady Randolph Churchill, daughter of Lawrence Jerome and sister of .illiam TraveIs Jerome. It was occupied from 1866 to 1881 by the Union League Club, and is being occupied by the University
Club from about 1884 to 1898.
bout 1890.
Brown Brothers.
